results.title: The Business of newspapers
results.brief_description: A comprehensive film examining the past present and future of the newspaper business. Issues covered include the influence of big businesses on journalism, the crisis of the survival of small-town newspapers, and how a newspaper’s editorial policies are being dictated by economic consideration. NB: The information in this film is very relevant to Australian media ownership in the 90’s.

results.title: The Business of change
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Francoise Fombertaux
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Change, particularly technological change, has become an unavoidable facet of daily life. In this changing world of work, to accept change has become a business - “being motivated to be motivated”. Teaching “change” is the new profession and trained psychologists are now moving into the area of business coaching - they are the highly skilled agents of change. Manufacturing and agricultural industries have decreased and have been replaced by the service industry which currently employs over 70% of the entire workforce in Australia. Professional people who have more money than time are increasingly outsourcing services, eg house maintenance and cleaning, pet care (professional dog walkers). Corporate, big business, and government agencies use Call Centres to centralise their customer service facilities. This program discusses motivational coaching as a means of helping people deal with change. Reference is also made to Frederick W. Taylor’s theory on organisational change, or Taylorism. Reporter: Tony Barrell.

results.title: The Business of aging
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Dennis McGann, Randy Sykes, Adam Symansky, Fred Tabachnick and Laszlo Barna
results.brief_description: This timely film raises the question of who should be entrusted with the care of the elderly and chronically ill—government-run or privately owned nursing homes. The Business of Aging looks into the quality of nursing home care in Canada and presents a sobering picture of residents caught in the financial squeeze as operators attempt to cut overheads at the expense of their patients.

results.title: The Business file.
results.creator_credit: Dallas County Community College and Paul Bosner
results.brief_description: Hosted by Alex Burton this series of four educational films deals with various topics related to marketing. Each program interviews academic experts on theory and then takes the example of one company’s approach to the topic in hand.

results.title: The Bushman goes home
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Eric Bedford
results.brief_description: A cattle station owner makes the long journey from his vast cattle station on the Gulf of Carpentaria to visit Melbourne and the cattle saleyards. He then flies back via the cattle fattening plains of New South Wales. Narrated by Nigel Lovell.

results.title: The Bushido blade
results.creator_credit: Trident Films, Rankin-Bass Productions, Bass, Arthur Rankin Jnr and Tom Kotani
results.brief_description: A co-production between the US and the UK, “The Bushido blade” is set in Japan in 1854 at the time when Commodore Matthew Perry (Richard Boone in his last film role) and his men sailed from the United States on a mission to Japan to sign a treaty uniting the two nations. As a sign of goodwill, the Shogun was to pass on the sacred Bushido Blade to Commodore Perry as a gift for the President of the United States but the Treaty would not be signed by the Japanese until the sacred sword was in Perry’s possession. To the Japanese, the Bushido Blade is a national symbol of the old ways, the Samurai tradition, and it has been this way for centuries. In the Shogun’s Commander’s (Toshiro Mifune) words “The sword is of spiritual character…Samurai warrior should live and die, sword in hand”. However, during the course of events, and just before the Treaty is to be signed, the Bushido Blade is stolen by a group of Samurai warriors opposed to the treaty and from there on in the remainder of the film is dedicated to the return of the blade. Based loosely on historical facts, the film proved to be a disappointment on release probably due to the low budget, poor scripting and not enough action (too much of the comedy and romance for dedicated fans of Japanese warrior films). It was eventually reissued under the title “The Bloody Bushido”. Cast also includes Sony Chiba, Laura Gemser, Frank Converse, James Earl Jones, Mako, Mayumi Atano, Timothy Murphy, Michael Starr.

results.title: The Bush myth
results.brief_description: This documentary is an examination of the way the bush myth has been portrayed in such Australian films as “The Sentimental Bloke”, “Sons of Matthew”, “Sunday too far away”, and “Picnic at Hanging Rock”. It covers the use of the bush motif throughout Australian history and how the interpretations and reactions to the landscape have changed so rapidly. It studies how the theme of nature versus culture has goverened almost all film making depicting the Australian bush until approximately 1982.

results.title: The Bus trip
results.brief_description: Ever gone on a trip and thought that maybe you left the oven on at home? In this entertaining film these kinds of speculations turn a simple cross country bus trip into a nightmare. Original Format 35mm/colour.

results.title: The Burning times
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Mary Armstrong, Margaret Pettigrew, Signe Johansson and Donna Read
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Women and spirituality”.
This beautifully crafted documentary is an in-depth look at the witch persecutions that swept through Europe just a few hundred years ago. False accusations and trials led to extensive torture and burnings at the stake, and ultimatley to the destruction of a way of life that had endured for thousands of years. Of those killed, 85% were women and widespread violence against women, still prevalent today, can be traced back to those times. It investigates the role of the Catholic Church in the crimes and explores the process whereby the old pagan communities, founded on spirituality and cooperation, were transformed into the misogynist capitalist societies of our own century.
